The '''Ringló''' was a cold and swift river<ref name=NM>{{NM|P3xxii}}, entry ''Ringló'', pp. 384-5</ref><ref name=Rivers>{{VT|42a}}, p. 9</ref> in the central regions of [[Gondor]].<ref name=FRmap>{{FR|Map}}</ref>

==Course==
The Ringló arose in a valley in the eastern part of [[Lamedon]]<ref name="RKmap">{{RK|Map}}</ref> in a high snowfield , which fed an icy pool that spread into a shallow lake at the snowmelting season.<ref name=NM/><ref name=Rivers/> From this source it flowed south-west for about 50 miles to [[Ethring]] where the road from the [[Hill of Erech]] to [[Linhir]] crossed the river.<ref name="RKmap"/> The Ringló continued south-west for another 50 miles to its confluence with the river [[Ciril]] and then flowed southwest for another 50 miles to its confluence with the river [[Morthond]] upstream of [[Edhellond]] before emptying near [[Cobas Haven]]<ref name="Map2">{{WR|3|XIV}}, West, p. 434</ref> into the [[Bay of Belfalas]].<ref name=FRmap/>

==History==
Near the confluence of the Ringló and the Morthond was the ancient Elf-haven of Edhellond. This refuge had been founded at the beginning of the [[Second Age]] by a remnant of [[Elves]] from [[Doriath]].<ref>{{UT|Galadriel}}, ''Amroth and Nimrodel''</ref>

After the founding of Gondor, the Ringló served as the boundary between [[Anfalas]] to the west and [[Belfalas]] to the east.<ref name="RKmap"/>

During the [[War of the Ring]] on [[9 March]] [[TA|3019]]<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 3019, March 9, p. 1093</ref> [[Dervorin]], the son of the lord of [[Ringló Vale]] arrived in [[Minas Tirith]] on foot with a company of three hundred men to aid in the city's defence.<ref>{{RK|MT}}, p. 770</ref> On [[10 March]] {{TA|3019}}<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3019, March 10, p. 1093</ref> [[Aragorn]], [[Gimli]], [[Legolas]], the [[Grey Company]], and the [[Oathbreakers|Army of the Dead]] crossed the Ringló on their way from [[Erech]] to [[Pelargir]].<ref>{{RK|Debate}}, p. 875</ref>

==Etymology==
''Ringló'' is a [[Sindarin]] name, which means "Chillflood".<ref name=NM/><ref name=Rivers/> It its composed of the elements ''ring'' ("cold", "chill")<ref>{{S|Appendix}}, ''ring''</ref> and ''ló'' ("flood").<ref name=NM/><ref name=Rivers/><ref>{{PE|17}}, entry S ''Ringló'' p. 96 and entry S '''Lhûn''', p. 136</ref>

Its name referred to the river's source, a high snowfield, which fed an icy pool that spread into a shallow lake at the snowmelting season.<ref name=NM/><ref name=Rivers/><ref>{{UT|Index}}, entry ''Ringló''</ref>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
The course and placement of the Ringló varied greatly as [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. In the [[The First Map of The Lord of the Rings|First Map of The Lord of the Rings]] the Ringló flowed to the sea and the Morthond was set well west of it (and [[Dol Amroth]] was far to the west of both).<ref>{{TI|MIII}}</ref> When he developed Outline VI for Book V in ''[[The Return of the King]]'' he drew a map that showed the Morthond east of the Ringló and the Ringló mostly flowed south to the Sea.<ref>{{WR|3|II}}</ref> When Tolkien made the detailed [[The Second Map of The Lord of the Rings|Second Map]] there were four rivers – [[Calenhir]], Morthond, Kiril (later Ciril), and Ringló – that flowed independently until they all met just before exiting into Cobas Haven.<ref name="Map2"/>

In two earlier versions of a note about the element ''ló'' in the name ''Gwathló'', it is mentioned that the Ringló formed marshes or a fenland after its confluence with the river Morthond as the reason for the element ló in the name Ringló. The second revised version mentioned that the river was named Ringnen after its source and later renamed Ringló, because it formed a fenland near its confluence with the Morthond. J.R.R. Tolkien later struck out the fenland as the explanation for the lement ''ló '' and stated in the final version that there is no record of any swamps or marsh in the course of the Ringló, but retained that the river was named after its source and explained it as mentioned above.<ref name=NM/><ref name=Rivers/>

==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''2014: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:Ringló originates in the "Ringló Vale" area of the Central [[Gondor]] in-game region, flowing through [[Ethring]] before entering [[Lamedon]] proper.
